pull_request.title: Add bulk actions to Unified Resources component
pull_request.body:
in support of https://github.com/gravitational/teleport/issues/30419
This is in support of bulk actions for other pages like access requests. it allows us to pass in custom functions/components to be added in the 'bulk actions' section. Left a `TODO` to remove Pinning in the same way but it's a much larger refactor so I left it out of this PR.

Also, a small update to a type.

This is in support of Unified Access Requests (which is coming in an `e` PR)

issue.title: Connect: Login form picks prefered auth connector over one that was actually used
issue.body:
Expected behavior:

If the cluster has `auth.type` set to local but I used GitHub to log in to the cluster, after the cert expires the login modal should automatically open the SSO form rather than the local form.

Current behavior:

If the cluster has `auth.type` set to local but I used GitHub to log in to the cluster, Connect always picks the auth method chosen in cluster config rather than the auth method I actually used.

This is because what auth method was used for the current session is not taken into account.

https://github.com/gravitational/teleport/blob/b5696c059e82157336c4b4b2f62f22549fbcba1a/web/packages/teleterm/src/ui/ClusterConnect/ClusterLogin/ClusterLogin.tsx#L100-L111

`auth` comes from here:

https://github.com/gravitational/teleport/blob/b5696c059e82157336c4b4b2f62f22549fbcba1a/web/packages/teleterm/src/ui/ClusterConnect/ClusterLogin/useClusterLogin.ts#L36-L46

comment.body: This code is so easy to follow 🤩

pull_request.title: Connect My Computer: Implement in-app flow after deep link click
pull_request.body:
Closes #32188.

This PR is a bunch of small commits followed by the final commit which actually implements the flow. Most of those earlier commits are either relevant cleanups we've been meaning to do for quite a while or additions to existing code to be able to implement the deep link click flow.

In general, when the user clicks on a Connect My Computer deep link, for example `teleport://alice@foo.example.com:3080/connect_my_computer`, the end goal is to open the Connect My Computer tab in the relevant workspace. See the demo video:

<details>
<summary>Demo video</summary>

https://github.com/gravitational/teleport/assets/27113/9dd25c9c-ab1f-45e3-8f1e-2ebd6a02e18a
</details>

If the relevant workspace doesn't exist yet, we have to show a login form with the cluster address and the username prefilled from the URL. [We shouldn't perform any actions with side effects](https://textslashplain.com/2019/08/29/web-to-app-communication-app-protocols/#careless-app-implementation) for the user, as they could be tricked by malicious website to open a `teleport://` link which automatically performs an action. That's why we're merely prefilling the modal instead of automatically adding a cluster (which makes the device running Connect send a ping to the cluster) and then asking for credentials.

The implementation from this PR opens the tab but it doesn't check if the user has permissions to use CMC. This will be addressed in the next PR.

You can test it yourself by packaging the app with the below command and then [opening a link from the fiddle](https://jsfiddle.net/ravicious/q0mgznv6/14/). I guess you first need to modify the hrefs of the deep links to match your local setup.

```
yarn build-term && CONNECT_TSH_BIN_PATH=$PWD/build/tsh yarn package-term
```

issue.title: Helm upgrade converting "on" to "true" for proxy_protocol which is giving the error - ERROR: invalid 'proxy_protocol' value "true". Available options are: [on off]
issue.body:
Expected behavior:
Teleport-cluster will be updated with the proxy_protocol without any issues.

Current behavior:
Helm upgrade converting "on" to "true" for proxy_protocol which is giving the error - ERROR: invalid 'proxy_protocol' value "true". Available options are: [on off]
Tried with --set-string for this parameter but it is including quotes which teleport-cluster chart is not allowing and throwing a different error.

Bug details:
- Teleport version - Teleport v14.0.0 git:api/v14.0.0-0-g599429b go1.21.1
- Recreation steps - upgrade teleport-cluster to 14.0 and use proxy_protocol in values file for the helm chart
- Debug logs

Thanks. I will update the cluster.

comment.body:
Ah good catch. `useKeyBasedPagination` has a custom check for abort errors:
```ts
const isAbortError = (err: any): boolean =>
  (err instanceof DOMException && err.name === 'AbortError') ||
  (err.cause && isAbortError(err.cause));
```
which doesn't catch our abort errors. I refactor this in https://github.com/gravitational/teleport/pull/33917/commits/f548c6989ff904836b3ed2c1a810085e1122e893 by adding a custom `AbortError` class, that both Connect and Web UI can throw in the service layer.

issue.title: Can not run gpushare command.
issue.body:
Hello team!

I have now successfully connected to the kubernetes cluster using tsh, but cannot run the `kubectl inspect gpushare -d` command. This command works fine for clusters that are not hosted by teleport.

As the pic shows, when I run `kubectl inspect gpushare -d`, it will prompt a certificate error.
![image](https://github.com/gravitational/teleport/assets/18479340/1c0f4a84-62e9-4a62-a633-3dc54a4489fc)

Do you have some ideas about that? Looking forward to your reply!

Thanks very much for your help!

issue.title: Applications with `public_addr` different than Teleport proxy based domain are not working
issue.body:
Expected behavior:
Creating web application with `public_addr` in different domain than the one used for teleport and pointing it to Teleport proxy should allow us to access that that application. Based on [this answer](https://github.com/gravitational/teleport/discussions/11290#discussioncomment-7186265) something like that should be possible now.

Current behavior:
It can be seen on this GIF
![error](https://github.com/gravitational/teleport/assets/62331374/74efd765-4fc2-45aa-ba47-d3fcba84f69d)

It looks like Teleport is in a loop when we have different domain in public address than the one for teleport.
Failing example: `public_addr` is set to `test.example.net` and teleport proxy exists in domain `example.com`. 
Working example:  `public_addr` is set to `test.example.com` and teleport proxy exists in domain `example.com`.

We have tested that behaviour in two different environments (one testing and one with load balancing and HA). We are owning tested domains and we have valid certificated attached to teleport proxy.

Bug details:
- Teleport version : 13.3 and 14.0
- Recreation steps:
1. Create two VMs: one for teleport proxy with auth and second one for teleport agent
2. Prepare valid certificates for both domains on proxy host
3. Install and configure teleport proxy and auth with simillar configuration like bellow:
```
version: v3
teleport:
  data_dir: /var/lib/teleport
  log:
    output: stderr
    severity: DEBUG
    format:
      output: text
  ca_pin: ""
  diag_addr: ""
auth_service:
  enabled: "yes"
  listen_addr: 0.0.0.0:3025
  proxy_listener_mode: multiplex
ssh_service:
  enabled: "no"
proxy_service:
  enabled: "yes"
  web_listen_addr: 0.0.0.0:443
  public_addr: YOUR_PROXY_ADDRESS:443
  https_keypairs:
    - key_file: /path/to/your/certs/DOMAIN_1.key
      cert_file: /path/to/your/certs/DOMAIN_1.crt
    - key_file: /path/to/your/certs/DOMAIN_2.key
      cert_file: /path/to/your/certs/DOMAIN_2.crt
  https_keypairs_reload_interval: 0s
  acme: {}
```
4. On Teleport agent create nginx container with docker compose config like bellow:
```
services:
  web.t.xxxxxxa.net:
    image: nginx:latest
    restart: always
    ports:
      - 80:80
```
5. Install teleport agent on second machine and configure it with simillar config:
```
version: v3
teleport:
  data_dir: /var/lib/teleport
  join_params:
    token_name: YOUR_JOIN_TOKEN
    method: token
  proxy_server: YOUR_PROXY_ADDRESS:443
  log:
    output: stderr
    severity: DEBUG
    format:
      output: text
  ca_pin: ""
  diag_addr: ""
auth_service:
  enabled: "no"
ssh_service:
  enabled: "yes"
  commands:
  - name: hostname
    command: [hostname]
    period: 1m0s
proxy_service:
  enabled: "no"
  https_keypairs: []
  https_keypairs_reload_interval: 0s
  acme: {}
app_service:
  enabled: "yes"
  debug_app: false
  apps:
  - name: web
    uri: http://localhost:80
    public_addr: "test.example.xyz"
    insecure_skip_verify: true
```
6. Point DNS record of the `public_addr` to teleport proxy ip address
7. Try to enter to the application via the teleport website or directlly
- Debug logs
logs from proxy/auth
```
teleport-t.example.com-1  | 2023-10-09T09:30:22Z DEBU [SSH:PROXY] Closed connection 10.200.2.31:59484. pid:7.1 sshutils/server.go:535
```

comment.body:
dup of https://github.com/gravitational/teleport/issues/26009

we are currently trying to fix this issue

just wanted to confirm, @wszychta from your gif, it looks like you are using firefox right? 

from my testing our current app access will not work with `public_addr` for safari, firefox, brave, and chrome incognito because these browser (or modes) block 3rd party cookie by default.

normal mode for chrome and edge should still work however (though chrome will also phase out 3rd party cookie by mid next year, but we should have a fix in before then).

issue.title: tsh proxy commands should bind on all addresses of loopback interface

labels.name: database-access
labels.description: Database access related issues and PRs

issue.body:
When `tsh` is used to run a proxy, that proxy is not bind on all addresses of the loopback interface.

It can create an unexpected behavior when another tool use `localhost` as domain endpoint to reach the target through the proxy, since that domain can be resolved with both of `127.0.0.1` and `[::1]` IPs

Expected behavior:
E.g for `tsh proxy db --db-name <dbname> --db-user <user> --port 12345 <target_name>`

```
ss -lptn | grep tsh
LISTEN 0      4096       127.0.0.1:12345      0.0.0.0:*    users:(("tsh",pid=277117,fd=8))        
LISTEN 0      4096           [::1]:12345         [::]:*    users:(("tsh",pid=277117,fd=9))        
```

Current behavior:

```
ss -lptn | grep tsh
LISTEN 0      4096       127.0.0.1:12345      0.0.0.0:*    users:(("tsh",pid=277117,fd=8))        
```

Bug details:
- Teleport version: tested with `tsh` binary build from 454bfc7280e6e640f54fc35eb89eea5e686a265b
- Recreation steps:
  - run tsh proxy command :  `tsh proxy db --db-name <dbname> --db-user <user> --port 12345 <target_name>`
  - look at binding : `ss -lptn | grep tsh`
- Debug logs: N/R

comment.body: @smallinsky This is not necessarily only for database-access, it's also true for app and kube proxies.

issue.title: Fix app redirection loop on browser's incognito mode and 3rd party cookie block
issue.body: resolves https://github.com/gravitational/teleport/issues/26009, https://github.com/gravitational/teleport/issues/15935 Updated RFD that explains the flow: https://github.com/gravitational/teleport/pull/31103 The cookie failure issue, is not a problem if an app is accessed by the default teleport subdomain. It becomes a problem if user sets a `public _addr` for the app where the domain is not teleports. Given SiteA (teleport) and SiteB (domain of app), the current implementation, responded with app cookies from SiteB, when the current site context was still on SiteA. To the browser this is considered 3rd party cookie and is blocked by default for the following major browsers (reproduced it too): - firefox: for both incognito and normal modes - safari: for both incognito and normal modes - brave - chrome: only incognito, however, google will be [phasing out 3rd party cookie](https://developer.chrome.com/en/docs/privacy-sandbox/third-party-cookie-phase-out/) by mid next year (2024) Our previous implementation that used the oauth state exchange flow was not affected by this problem because we set the app cookies while we are in the app domain. This PR reverts some parts of the current implementation with the previous implementation with some small refactors, notably the state token race condition which was resolved by creating unique cookies for each state token created. #### Tested Tested the following by updating teleport versions (from my reproduction steps) that includes this PR's changes: - with updated cluster and app service still running previous version - github login Local testing to test parameters are getting saved: - redirecting with github login and local login with this URL: https://grafana-test-127-0-0-1.nip.io:3080/alerting/list?search=state:inactive%20type:alerting%20health:nodata With Browsers: - firefox both incognito and normal - as suggested by [google](https://developer.chrome.com/en/docs/privacy-sandbox/third-party-cookie-phase-out/#debugging-cookies), tested in chrome by running the following in CLI `/Applications/Google\ Chrome.app/Contents/MacOS/Google\ Chrome --test-third-party-cookies-phaseout` #### Reproduction Running version: `Teleport Enterprise v15.0.0-dev git:pull-4093-g68d8647cd6 go1.21.3` (before this PR) - Create two ec2 instances - On the main cluster, install [certbot](https://certbot.eff.org/instructions?ws=webproduct&os=ubuntufocal), then create two certs (one for cluster and one for app) and include them in main teleport config under `proxy_service.https_keypairs` (note: need to add inbound rule for port 80) - start teleport with config - point custom domain (`kimlisa.app`) to this cluster's ip address (eg: `3.83.9.149`): ec2 instance 1 (main cluster) cfg: ``` version: v3 teleport: nodename: ip-172-31-93-149 data_dir: /var/lib/teleport log: output: stderr severity: INFO format: output: text ca_pin: "" diag_addr: "" auth_service: enabled: "yes" listen_addr: 0.0.0.0:3025 cluster_name: root.3.83.9.149.nip.io license_file: /var/lib/teleport/license.pem proxy_listener_mode: multiplex authentication: type: local second_factor: off ssh_service: enabled: "yes" commands: - name: hostname command: [hostname] period: 1m0s proxy_service: enabled: "yes" web_listen_addr: 0.0.0.0:443 public_addr: root.3.83.9.149.nip.io:443 https_keypairs: - key_file: /etc/letsencrypt/live/app1.kimlisa.app/privkey.pem cert_file: /etc/letsencrypt/live/app1.kimlisa.app/fullchain.pem - key_file: /etc/letsencrypt/live/root.3.83.9.149.nip.io/privkey.pem cert_file: /etc/letsencrypt/live/root.3.83.9.149.nip.io/fullchain.pem https_keypairs_reload_interval: 0s acme: {} ``` ec2 instance 2 for app. - run whatever app (mine is running on `http://localhost:4000`) - copy and paste the output from running `./tctl tokens add` in ec2 instance 1 - manually add a `public-addr` flag to custom domain ``` ubuntu@ip:~/teleport/e/build$ sudo ./tctl tokens add \ --type=app \ --app-name=test-app-1 \ --app-uri=http://localhost:4000 The invite token: 3c3... This token will expire in 30 minutes. Fill out and run this command on a node to make the application available: > teleport app start \ --token=3c3... \ --ca-pin=sha256:80... \ --auth-server=root.3.83.9.149.nip.io:443 \ --name=test-app-1 \ --uri=http://localhost:4000 \ --public-addr=app1.kimlisa.app ```
